SafetyInspectionBy: Paul Akers Inc. the Installation contractor

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary for Premier Ag, LLC, Franklin Crops



1. The Facility Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The owners, management, and employees of Premier Ag, LLC are committed to the prevention of any

accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to

work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of

the release to people and the environment.



2. The Facility and the Regulated Substance(s) Handled

This facility is a retail farm supply center and handles a variety of farm supplies, including dry and liquid

fertilizers, crop protection products, seed, and other related agricultural inputs. This facility is a retailer of

anhydrous ammonia, a product regulated by U. S. EPA. We receive anhydrous ammonia by truck, store that

product on-site in one 26,000 gallon storage tank and then distribute the product to our customers in 1,000

gallon and 1,450 gallon nurse tanks. The only processes related to anhydrous ammonia at this location are

using a liquid pump to move the product from the delivery truck into the storage tank, and then using a liquid

pump to move the product from the storage tank into the 1,000 gallon and 1,450 gallon nurse tanks.



3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific

Prevention Steps

This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of

Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. This facility also

complies with the standards of the U. S Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR

1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Additional information is contained in our "Safety

and Environmental Manual". Other steps used to prevent the accidental release of ammonia include routine

safety and maintenance inspections, employ

ee training, and the use of specific devices that have been shown

to be effective in mitigating accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.



4. The Five Year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that have caused any

deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility or, to our knowledge, have resulted in off-site

injuries, property damage, or environmental damage.



5. The Emergency Response Program

This facility has a written Emergency Response Plan, in accordance with OSHA standards 29 CFR 1910.38 and

29 CFR 1910.120. We also have provided state and local authorities with the emergency planning and

community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA). All employees receive ongoing training related to safe handling procedures for ammonia, equipment maintenance, and personal

protective equipment requirements. All employees are also prepared to implement the Emergency Response

Plan as outlined for the facility.



6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Safety improvement is an ongoing process at this facility. Periodic inspections and checklists are performed

to assess the maintenance and safety conditions of all components in the ammonia handling process. There

are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
